lead_paragraph: PRICE--Robert. August 27, 1932 - April 22, 2016. In Loving Memory of Robert Price, Father, Grandfather, Attorney, Political Strategist, Deputy Mayor, Businessman, Philanthropist, and Veteran died early on Friday, April 22 at age 83. He was predeceased by his wife Margery. He is survived by his children and their spouses Eileen and Steven Farbman and Steven and Tina Price, his grandchildren Alexandra and Ben (spouse), Leo, Lucy, and Kyle, and his sister Myrna Holzman. Filled with optimism, grit, and determination, he lived fully, deeply and passionately loved his family and friends, was always thinking, pushing, driving forward and was imbued with faith. He mastered the art of politics, business and philanthropy. The world was a better place because of his presence. Robert Price was born in the Bronx and proudly lived in New York City all his life. He was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, New York University, and Columbia Law School. He served to Corporal in the United States Army from 1953-55. He practiced law in New York City and was a member of the New York and several Federal bars, including the Second Circuit and United States Supreme Court. He served as Assistant United States Attorney (Criminal Division) for the Southern District of New York from 1959-60. Price loved politics from an early age, and at age 19 introduced future President Dwight Eisenhower at a Madison Square Garden rally. Price found his calling as a campaign manager and never lost an election. He was campaign manager for his friend John Lindsay's Congressional elections from 1958-64, and was campaign manager when Lindsay won the New York City mayoralty in 1965. Price also served as campaign manager for Nelson Rockefeller's only victory in a presidential primary, in Oregon in 1964, and was campaign manager for his former law partner Theodore Kupferman's election to Congress in 1966. Price served as Deputy Mayor of New York City from 1966-67, and was profiled on the cover of The New York Times Magazine. He was named one of the Junior Chamber of Commerce's Ten Outstanding Young Men in 1966, along with Joseph Califano and Ralph Nader. Price left politics to become a successful businessman. He was Director and Executive Vice President of The Dreyfus Corporation and Investment Officer of The Dreyfus Fund from 1967-69, President of Price Capital Corporation from 1969-72, and General Partner and General Counsel of Lazard Freres & Co. from 1972-79. He was the founder, Chairman, and President of Price Communications Corporation from 1979-2007, and also the founder of PriCellular Corporation, of which he was Director and President from 1990-97 and Chairman from 1997-98. He was a longstanding member of Park Avenue Synagogue. He was also a proud member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He served as Representative of the Majority Leader and President Pro Tem of the New York Senate and as a member of the Board of Directors and Vice Chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York. He also served as the Governor of New York State's nominee as trustee of the City University of New York and was a commissioner on the New York State Commission of Investigations. The Robert Price Center for Environmental Studies in Jerusalem is named in his honor. For those who wish to make a contribution, please send any donations, in memory of Robert Price, to the Center for Israel Studies at Columbia Law School or the Icahn School of Medicine at Mt. Sinai. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3
